unnormalised: The yellowed file in my hand felt heavier than its 25 pages suggested. It was my grandfather’s medical record, compiled over decades at various hospitals across Chennai. The sheer volume of numbers documenting his life – his blood pressure consistently hovering around 140/90 mmHg, his weight fluctuating between 75 kg and 80 kg, his cholesterol levels perpetually above 200 mg/dL – was overwhelming. Each digit told a story of its own, a silent narrative of aging and health.

unnormalised: I remember Appa, my grandfather, always complaining about his sugar levels. The records showed a steady climb, starting from a manageable 110 mg/dL fasting to a worrying 180 mg/dL by his late 70s. His HbA1c, that dreaded number, stubbornly remained around 7.5%, despite countless trips to Dr. Rao at Apollo. He used to joke, “These numbers are trying to kill me, beta!” But beneath the humor, I saw his quiet worry.
